item.title: Voice and Data Bandwidth for Hospitals
item.description: Healthcare facilities rely heavily on electronic communication to function effectively. This reliance is only expected to increase as technology advances and electronic record-keeping becomes more common. This naturally raises concerns about the rising costs associated with these growing telecom needs. However, there are ways to manage and even reduce these expenses. The most fundamental requirement for any organization is voice communication. For larger facilities, this typically involves a PBX phone system.

item.title: The EU’s Patients’ Rights Directive in practice
item.description: Tamara Hervey, Professor of Law and Head of Law School, University of Sheffield As Europe focuses on the immense refugee crisis, discussing other migration matters can seem trivial. However, this week also saw the release of the European Commission’s report on the “Patients’ Rights Directive.” This report reveals that the directive’s name is misleading, as its primary goal appears to be safeguarding national health systems instead of patients’ rights.

item.title: Part 1 of the European Commission Draft Withdrawal Agreement text explores the impact on health, focusing on patients and reciprocal healthcare.
item.description: Tamara K Hervey, Jean Monnet Professor of EU Law, University of Sheffield This article provides an initial examination of the European Commission’s draft Withdrawal Agreement and its effects on health-related issues, particularly concerning individuals. The focus here is on patient rights, specifically reciprocal healthcare between the UK and the remaining 27 EU members post-Brexit. Two significant issues are explored: The future of UK pensioners residing in or planning to retire in other EU countries.

item.title: Part 1: The Impact of the Revised European Commission Draft Withdrawal Agreement on Health - Patients and Reciprocal Healthcare (Updated as of March 18, 2018)
item.description: Tamara K Hervey, holding the Jean Monnet Chair in EU Law at the University of Sheffield, has reviewed the European Commission’s revised draft legal text on the Withdrawal Agreement (WA) as of March 15, 2018. Her analysis focuses on how the revised text impacts reciprocal healthcare between the UK and the EU-27 post-Brexit, particularly for UK pensioners residing in other EU countries and the use of the European Health Insurance Card (EHIC) for emergency care.

item.title: New ruling from the ECtHR changes the landscape of ECHR and EU law regarding the expulsion of seriously ill migrants.

item.title: Analysis 1: Examination of Healthcare Entitlements in the EU-UK Trade and Cooperation Agreement
item.description: Professor Tamara Hervey from the University of Sheffield examines the healthcare entitlements, if any, provided by the EU-UK Trade and Cooperation Agreement (TCA) that was provisionally agreed upon on December 24, 2020. Introduction The TCA includes provisions for social security coordination, similar to EU law but considerably weaker. These provisions are found in Heading Four and are not typical of standard trade agreements like CETA. Many are interested in the future of the European Health Insurance Card (EHIC) scheme, as private travel insurance is often expensive or inaccessible, particularly for the elderly.
